questions.text: A lesion of the structure marked in the image below cause?( AIIMS May 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Contralateral hemiplegia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The structure marked in the image is the pyramid containing the pyramidal tracts. A lesion here leads to contralateral hemiplegia.
  • • This is because the fibers of these tracts decussate (cross over) in the medulla oblongata. Thus, an injury to the pyramidal tract on one side of the brain or upper spinal cord will affect motor function on the opposite side of the body.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Ataxia : Ataxia refers to uncoordinated movement and is typically related to damage to the cerebellum or sensory pathways, not the pyramidal tracts. The cerebellum plays a crucial role in fine-tuning motor movements and ensuring coordination. So, an injury to the pyramidal tracts does not typically result in ataxia.
  • • Option B.
  • • Ataxia
  • • Option C. Tinnitus : Tinnitus is the perception of noise or ringing in the ears. It's a symptom of an underlying condition, such as age-related hearing loss, ear injury, or a circulatory system disorder. Injury to the pyramidal tracts would not lead to tinnitus, as they are primarily motor tracts and not involved in auditory processing or function.
  • • Option C.
  • • Tinnitus
  • • Option D. Ipsilateral facial palsy : Facial palsy refers to weakness or paralysis of the muscles on one side of the face. It is most commonly associated with damage to the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII). While the pyramidal tracts do play a role in voluntary facial movements, a direct injury to these tracts would not typically lead to ipsilateral facial palsy. Furthermore, facial movements are controlled by both sides of the brain, so an isolated pyramidal tract lesion might not manifest as overt facial weakness.
  • • Option D.
  • • Ipsilateral facial palsy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The pyramids in the medulla oblongata, containing the pyramidal tracts, are crucial for voluntary motor control. A lesion here can lead to contralateral hemiplegia due to the crossing over of these tracts within the medulla. This understanding is essential for diagnosing and understanding the implications of brainstem injuries, especially in the context of stroke or other neurological disorders.

questions.text: The blood supply to the structure marked in the image is by? ( AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Anterior cerebral artery

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The marked structure is fornix which is supplied by the anterior cerebral artery.
  • • The optic chiasma, lamina terminalis, hypothalamus, para-olfactory regions, and cingulate gyrus are all supplied by the anteromedial central branches of the anterior cerebral artery in addition to the fornix.
  • • The fornix is a C-shaped bundle of nerve fibers in the brain that plays a crucial role in memory and cognitive functions. It is supplied by
  • • Anterior Cerebral Artery (ACA): The ACA is one of the major arteries of the Circle of Willis and is responsible for supplying blood to the frontal lobes of the brain, including the anterior part of the fornix. Posterior Cerebral Artery (PCA): The PCA is another major artery of the Circle of Willis, and its branches supply blood to the posterior part of the fornix. Anterior Choroidal Artery: This artery arises from the internal carotid artery and supplies blood to the choroid plexus in the lateral and third ventricles of the brain. It also sends branches to the fornix, particularly the inferior part. Septal Branches: The fornix also receives blood supply from septal branches, which originate from the anterior cerebral arteries. questions.text: A young patient presented with hypoparathyroidism, absent thymus and tetany. Which of the following marked areas in the picture is defective in this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. 12

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The given clinical scenario of hypoparathyroidism, absent thymus, and tetany is suggestive of DiGeorge syndrome. It is caused by defective development of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouch.
  • • In the image of pharyngeal pouches, "12" points to the thymus (derivative of 3rd pharyngeal pouch). Since in the above question, the thymus is absent, option 3 will be the most appropriate answer.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. (1): 1st Pharyngeal pouches, which is unrelated to the thymus or parathyroid glands directly involved in this case.
  • • Option A. (1):
  • • Option B. (10): External auditory meatus, which is not implicated in DiGeorge syndrome.
  • • Option B. (10):
  • • Option D. (13): Superior parathyroid gland, derived from the fourth pharyngeal pouch. Although it's closely related to the condition described, the primary indicator in this scenario, given the patient's symptoms, is the thymus rather than the parathyroid glands.
  • • Option D. (13):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ DiGeorge syndrome, also known as 22q11.2 deletion syndrome, is a genetic disorder caused by a missing piece of chromosome 22. It is characterized by a wide range of symptoms that can vary in severity, but are typically grouped together as mnemonic CATCH -22
  • ➤ Mnemonic "CATCH-22":
  • ➤ Mnemonic "CATCH-22":
  • ➤ C - Cardiac abnormalities, such as ventricular septal defects (VSD) and tetralogy of Fallot.
  • ➤ A - Abnormal facies, including a small chin, low-set ears, and wide-set eyes.
  • ➤ T - Thymic aplasia or hypoplasia, leading to a weakened immune system.
  • ➤ C - Cleft palate or other palate abnormalities.
  • ➤ H - Hypocalcemia or low levels of calcium due to underdeveloped or missing parathyroid glands.
  • ➤ 22 - Refers to the chromosome 22q11.2 deletion, which causes the syndrome.

questions.text: Identify the marked chamber? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)

The base (posterior surface) of the heart is mainly formed by the left atrium (two-thirds) and the right atrium (one-third).
  • • In the image, the vertebra is at the back, and the aorta is on the left side in front of the vertebra. The esophagus is closely related to the base of the heart, particularly the left atrium. The chamber marked in the question is the one just in front of the esophagus is the left atrium.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:

  • • Option A. Right atrium:
  • • Option C. Right ventricle: The right ventricle lies on the front side along with the right atrium. It forms the sternocostal surface of the heart. The marked chamber is at the back, so it cannot be the right ventricle.
  • • Option C. Right ventricle:
  • • Option D. Left ventricle : The left ventricle lies next to the left atrium at the back in this transverse section. However, the marked chamber is the one closest to the esophagus, which is the left atrium, not the left ventricle.

questions.text: The talocalcaneonavicular joint is a?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Ball and socket joint

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The talocalcaneonavicular joint is a ball and socket joint.
  • • The ball part is formed by the rounded head of the talus. The socket is formed by 3 structures: Posterior surface of the navicular Anterior articular surface of the calcaneus Upper surface of the plantar calcaneo-navicular ligament (spring ligament).
  • • The ball part is formed by the rounded head of the talus.
  • • The socket is formed by 3 structures: Posterior surface of the navicular Anterior articular surface of the calcaneus Upper surface of the plantar calcaneo-navicular ligament (spring ligament).
  • • Posterior surface of the navicular Anterior articular surface of the calcaneus Upper surface of the plantar calcaneo-navicular ligament (spring ligament).
  • • Posterior surface of the navicular
  • • Anterior articular surface of the calcaneus
  • • Upper surface of the plantar calcaneo-navicular ligament (spring ligament).
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Saddle Type: A saddle joint, also known as a sellar joint, is a type of synovial joint found in the thumb (between the trapezium bone and the first metacarpal bone). It allows movement in two planes, such as flexion-extension and abduction-adduction. The talocalcaneonavicular joint does not fit this description.
  • • Option A. Saddle Type:
  • • Option B. Plane: A plane joint, also called a gliding joint, allows for limited sliding or gliding movements between flat articular surfaces. While there are gliding joints in the foot, the talocalcaneonavicular joint is not primarily classified as a plane joint.
  • • Option B. Plane:
  • • Option C. Ellipsoid (Condyloid): An ellipsoid joint, also known as a condyloid joint, is a synovial joint that allows movement in two planes: flexion-extension and abduction-adduction. This type of joint has an oval-shaped convex surface fitting into an elliptical concave surface.
  • • Option C. Ellipsoid (Condyloid):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A ball and socket joint is characterized by a spherical head fitting into a cup-like socket. This type of joint allows for a wide range of motion in multiple planes. The talocalcaneonavicular joint is a ball and socket joint.

questions.text: While administering epidural anesthesia, which structure is not punctured before injecting the drug? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Arachnoid mater

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • During epidural anesthesia, the anesthetic agent is injected into the epidural space, which lies outside the dura mater. The needle passes through several layers of tissue but does not puncture the dura mater, arachnoid mater, or enter the subarachnoid space.
  • • The layers that are punctured during epidural anesthesia, in order, are:
  • • Skin Superficial fascia Supraspinous ligament Interspinous ligament Ligamentum flavum
  • • Skin
  • • Superficial fascia
  • • Supraspinous ligament
  • • Interspinous ligament
  • • Ligamentum flavum
  • • After passing through the ligamentum flavum, the needle enters the epidural space, where the anesthetic agent is deposited.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Supraspinous ligament : This ligament is punctured during epidural anesthesia.
  • • Option A. Supraspinous ligament
  • • Option B. Interspinous ligament : This ligament is also punctured during the procedure.
  • • Option B. Interspinous ligament
  • • Option C. Ligamentum flavum : The needle passes through the ligamentum flavum to reach the epidural space.
  • • Option C. Ligamentum flavum :
  • • Note : that this procedure differs from a lumbar puncture, where the needle passes through the dura mater, arachnoid mater, and enters the subarachnoid space (represented by the mnemonic "DAS": Dura mater, Arachnoid mater, Subarachnoid space).
  • • Note

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ During epidural anesthesia, the arachnoid mater is not punctured. The anesthetic agent is injected into the epidural space, which lies outside the dura mater, after passing through the skin, superficial fascia, supraspinous ligament, interspinous ligament, and ligamentum flavum.

questions.text: All of the following supply the structure marked ‘E’ except? ( AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Diagonal artery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understanding the vascular supply of the heart is crucial, especially in clinical settings dealing with coronary artery disease. The right ventricle is primarily supplied by the right coronary artery and its branches, including the marginal artery. The diagonal artery, a branch of the left coronary system (specifically the anterior interventricular artery), mainly supplies the left ventricle and does not contribute significantly to the blood supply of the right ventricle.

questions.text: In a RTA (road traffic accident), a person suffered from injury to the membranous urethra. What can be the location of the collection of the urine due to this injury? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Deep perineal pouch

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Injury to the membranous urethra, which traverses through the urogenital diaphragm, leads to urine collection in specific anatomical spaces:
  • • The membranous urethra is surrounded by the external urethral sphincter within the deep perineal pouch When ruptured, urine initially collects in the deep perineal pouch due to the confined anatomical space The fascial boundaries of the deep perineal pouch limit the spread initially
  • • The membranous urethra is surrounded by the external urethral sphincter within the deep perineal pouch
  • • When ruptured, urine initially collects in the deep perineal pouch due to the confined anatomical space
  • • The fascial boundaries of the deep perineal pouch limit the spread initially
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Peritoneal cavity: Incorrect. The membranous urethral injury doesn't communicate with the peritoneal cavity due to anatomical barriers.
  • • Option B. Peritoneal cavity:
  • • Option C. Anterior abdominal wall: Incorrect. This is typically seen in bulbar urethral injuries where urine tracks along Buck's fascia into the anterior abdominal wall.
  • • Option C. Anterior abdominal wall:
  • • Option D. Ischiorectal fossa: Incorrect. While adjacent to the deep perineal pouch, the ischiorectal fossa is separated by fascial planes and isn't a primary collection site for membranous urethral injuries.
  • • Option D. Ischiorectal fossa:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Membranous urethral injuries result in urine collection within the deep perineal pouch due to its anatomical location and fascial boundaries, unlike bulbar urethral injuries which track to the anterior abdominal wall.

questions.text: A patient sustained an injury to the head and now presents with blood collected around his eyes. Attachment of which of the following structures leads to this condition? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Loose areolar layer

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The condition, where blood collects around the eyes following a head injury, is known as " raccoon eyes" or "black eyes".
  • • raccoon eyes" or "black eyes".
  • • Layers of the scalp -
  • • Layers of the scalp -
  • • The scalp consists of five layers, which can be remembered using the mnemonic "SCALP":
  • • mnemonic "SCALP":
  • • Skin Connective tissue (superficial fascia) Aponeurotic layer (epicranial aponeurosis) Loose areolar layer Periosteum (pericranium)
  • • Skin
  • • Connective tissue (superficial fascia)
  • • Aponeurotic layer (epicranial aponeurosis)
  • • Loose areolar layer
  • • Periosteum (pericranium)
  • • Among these layers, the loose areolar layer (4th layer) is the key to understanding the development of raccoon eyes. This layer lacks bony attachments anteriorly and is continuous with the eyelids. When a head injury occurs, the emissary veins or other vessels in this layer may rupture, causing blood to accumulate. Since the loose areolar layer is continuous with the eyelids, the blood can easily spread and collect around the eyes, resulting in the characteristic black eye appearance.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Superficial fascia: Incorrect. Although the superficial fascia is one of the layers of the scalp, it is not the layer responsible for the continuity with the eyelids and the development of raccoon eyes.
  • • Option A. Superficial fascia:
  • • Option C. Periosteum: Incorrect. The periosteum, also known as the pericranium, is the innermost layer of the scalp, firmly attached to the underlying bone. It does not have continuity with the eyelids and is not the cause of raccoon eyes.
  • • Option C. Periosteum:
  • • Option D. Pericranium: Incorrect. The pericranium is another name for the periosteum, the innermost layer of the scalp. It is not responsible for the development of raccoon eyes.
  • • Option D. Pericranium:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The loose areolar layer of the scalp, which lacks bony attachments anteriorly and is continuous with the eyelids, is responsible for the development of raccoon eyes following a head injury due to the accumulation and spread of blood from ruptured vessels.

It occurs as a result of puncture of intrapericardial superior vena cava, right atrium, or right ventricle. Pneumothorax- injury to the underlying pleura may lead to pneumothorax. This is more common in subclavian vein catheterization. Chylothorax can occur particularly in left subclavian vein catheterization. But it is not the most common. While thrombophlebitis can occur following any central line placement, it's more commonly associated with peripheral IV lines. However, central venous catheters are more commonly associated with deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which is the formation of a blood clot inside the larger, deeper veins.

While empyema itself is not a direct complication of central line placement, pneumothorax or hemothorax (air or blood in the pleural space, respectively) caused by central line placement can lead to infection and subsequently empyema if not recognized and treated.

questions.text: Meiosis occurs in:(NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Adult ovary
  • ➤ arrested in prophase I
  • ➤ After puberty, with each menstrual cycle, some oocytes resume meiosis, completing meiosis I and arresting in meiosis II. It's only after fertilization that meiosis II completes . Therefore, meiosis occurs in the adult ovary as it is essential for the formation of mature ova or egg cells.

questions.text: A patient who has taken the first COVID vaccine comes for the second dose. An astute nurse noticed that the shoulder was flabby, flat, and was asymmetrical. There was an associated loss of contour of the shoulder joint. Injury to which of the structures might have resulted and was avoidable?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Axillary nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The axillary nerve arises from the posterior cord of the brachial plexus and supplies the deltoid muscle and the teres minor muscle. It also carries sensory fibers for the skin over a part of the deltoid (known as the "regimental badge area").
  • ➤ Damage to the axillary nerve can result from shoulder dislocations or, as in this case, a vaccine administered too high on the arm. Injury to the axillary nerve would cause paralysis of the deltoid muscle, leading to a flat shoulder appearance and loss of the normal rounded contour of the deltoid. Over time, if the nerve does not recover, the deltoid muscle may atrophy, further accentuating the flat appearance.

questions.text: Which of the following structures passing via jugular foramen has a separate canal?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Glossopharyngeal nerve

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The glossopharyngeal nerve passing through the jugular foramen has a separate canal.
  • • The glossopharyngeal nerve is the ninth cranial nerve, and it is responsible for providing sensory and motor innervation to the tongue, pharynx, and certain structures in the head and neck region . It originates in the brainstem, specifically from the medulla oblongata, and has both sensory and motor components.
  • • sensory and motor innervation to the tongue, pharynx, and certain structures in the head and neck region
  • • The sensory branches of the glossopharyngeal nerve are responsible for providing sensation to the back of the tongue, tonsils, pharynx, middle ear, and the carotid sinus (which is a baroreceptor that helps regulate blood pressure). It also plays a role in taste sensation for the posterior third of the tongue.
  • • The motor branches of the glossopharyngeal nerve are responsible for controlling the muscles of the pharynx and the parotid gland, which is a salivary gland located in the cheek. Dysfunction of the glossopharyngeal nerve can result in symptoms such as difficulty swallowing, decreased taste sensation, and a decreased gag reflex.
  • • The glossopharyngeal nerve leaves the skull through the anteromedial part of the jugular foramen in a separate dural sheath.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Hypoglossal Nerve (CN XII) : The hypoglossal nerve passes through the hypoglossal canal, which is a separate opening located just anterior to the jugular foramen. This nerve controls the muscles of the tongue.
  • • Option A. Hypoglossal Nerve (CN XII)
  • • Option C. Vagus Nerve (CN X): The vagus nerve is another cranial nerve that passes through the jugular foramen. It does not have a separate canal within the jugular foramen. The vagus nerve has numerous functions, including control of the heart, lungs, and digestive organs.
  • • Option C. Vagus Nerve (CN X):
  • • Option D. Accessory Nerve (CN XI): The accessory nerve enters the jugular foramen alongside the vagus and glossopharyngeal nerves. It also does not have a separate canal within the jugular foramen. This nerve controls the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles.
  • • Option D. Accessory Nerve (CN XI):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The glossopharyngeal nerve is unique among the nerves passing through the jugular foramen as it occupies a separate canal. Understanding this anatomical detail is vital for surgical navigation and for diagnosing nerve pathologies that may affect swallowing, taste, and autonomic functions in the neck and head region.

questions.text: Which of the following layers is absent in the esophagus? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The esophagus is a tubular structure located in the thoracic cavity, connecting the pharynx to the stomach. Unlike most of the gastrointestinal tract, the esophagus lacks a serosa layer. The serosa is a thin membrane derived from the peritoneum, which is a structure found in the abdominal cavity. Since the esophagus is primarily located in the thoracic cavity, it does not have a serosa layer covering its external surface.
  • • However, it is important to note that the short, intra-abdominal portion of the esophagus (just before it connects to the stomach) is covered by a serosa layer derived from the peritoneum. This portion is an exception to the general rule that the esophagus lacks a serosa.
  • • The esophageal wall is composed of the following layers from the lumen outwards:
  • • The esophageal wall is composed of the following layers from the lumen outwards:
  • • Mucosa: The innermost layer, consisting of epithelium, lamina propria, and muscularis mucosae. Submucosa: A layer of connective tissue containing blood vessels, lymphatics, and esophageal glands. Muscularis externa (or muscularis propria): Consists of an inner circular layer and an outer longitudinal layer of smooth muscle. Adventitia: The outermost layer of the esophagus, composed of loose connective tissue. This layer is not called serosa because it is not derived from the peritoneum.
  • • Mucosa: The innermost layer, consisting of epithelium, lamina propria, and muscularis mucosae.
  • • Mucosa:
  • • Submucosa: A layer of connective tissue containing blood vessels, lymphatics, and esophageal glands.

  • • Muscularis externa (or muscularis propria): Consists of an inner circular layer and an outer longitudinal layer of smooth muscle.
  • • Muscularis externa (or muscularis propria):
  • • Adventitia: The outermost layer of the esophagus, composed of loose connective tissue. This layer is not called serosa because it is not derived from the peritoneum.
  • • Adventitia:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Mucosa: Incorrect. The mucosa is present in the esophagus and forms the innermost layer.
  • • Option A. Mucosa:
  • • Option B. Submucosa: Incorrect. The submucosa is present in the esophagus and lies between the mucosa and muscularis externa.
  • • Option B. Submucosa:
  • • Option C. Muscularis externa: Incorrect. The muscularis externa is present in the esophagus and consists of two layers of smooth muscle.
  • • Option C. Muscularis externa:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The esophagus lacks a serosa layer because it is primarily located in the thoracic cavity, except for the short intra-abdominal portion just before it connects to the stomach.

questions.text: Which of the following features differentiates the exocrine pancreas from the parotid gland? ( INICET May 2020)

options.label: A
options.text: Basal lamina lining the serous acini

options.label: C
options.text: Presence of serous acini with acidophilic tip

questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Absence of striated duct

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Striated ducts are a characteristic feature of salivary glands, including the parotid gland. These ducts have basal infoldings associated with mitochondria, which gives them their "striated" appearance. They play a role in modifying the primary saliva produced by the acinar cells. The exocrine pancreas does not possess striated ducts. Instead, it has intercalated ducts that connect the acinar cells to the larger duct system. This feature, therefore, differentiates the exocrine pancreas from the parotid gland .

These ducts have basal infoldings associated with mitochondria, which gives them their "striated" appearance. They play a role in modifying the primary saliva produced by the acinar cells. The exocrine pancreas does not possess striated ducts. Instead, it has intercalated ducts that connect the acinar cells to the larger duct system. This feature, therefore, differentiates the exocrine pancreas from the parotid gland .
  • ➤ differentiates the exocrine pancreas from the parotid gland

Dysphagia (Difficulty Swallowing): When the thyroid gland enlarges and presses against the esophagus (the tube that carries food from the mouth to the stomach), it can interfere with the normal swallowing process, leading to dysphagia or difficulty swallowing. Thyroid enlargement can affect sympathetic nerve fibers and lead to these symptoms. Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve - a. Hoarseness: The recurrent laryngeal nerve innervates the muscles responsible for vocal cord movement. Compression or damage to this nerve due to thyroid enlargement can result in hoarseness of voice and voice changes.

questions.text: Which of the following is connected to the structure marked as A in the image below?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Striate cortex

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The structure marked A in the above image is the splenium of the corpus callosum and it is connected to the striate cortex. The striate cortex, also known as the primary visual cortex or V1, is involved in early visual processing, such as processing basic features of visual stimuli like edges, orientation, and motion. It does have connections to the splenium of the corpus callosum, especially for the transfer of visual information between the hemispheres. This connection allows the brain to process visual information from both eyes and integrate it into a cohesive visual experience. The splenium of the corpus callosum primarily connects various regions of the cerebral hemispheres, facilitating communication between the left and right cerebral hemispheres .
  • • The structure marked A in the above image is the splenium of the corpus callosum and it is connected to the striate cortex.
  • • The striate cortex, also known as the primary visual cortex or V1, is involved in early visual processing, such as processing basic features of visual stimuli like edges, orientation, and motion. It does have connections to the splenium of the corpus callosum, especially for the transfer of visual information between the hemispheres. This connection allows the brain to process visual information from both eyes and integrate it into a cohesive visual experience.
  • • The splenium of the corpus callosum primarily connects various regions of the cerebral hemispheres, facilitating communication between the left and right cerebral hemispheres .
  • • .
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Orbital Cortex: The orbital cortex is involved in various aspects of emotional processing and decision-making. It is not directly connected to the splenium of the corpus callosum.
  • • Option A. Orbital Cortex:
  • • Option B. Hippocampus: The hippocampus is a crucial structure for memory formation and spatial navigation. While it has connections to other parts of the brain, its primary connection to the corpus callosum is through the more anterior parts, not the splenium.
  • • Option B. Hippocampus:
  • • Option D. Optic Chiasma: The optic chiasma is not directly connected to the splenium of the corpus callosum. It is a structure located at the base of the brain where some of the optic nerve fibers from each eye cross over to the opposite side of the brain. This crossover allows for the integration of visual input from both eyes, but it occurs before the information reaches the corpus callosum.
  • • Option D. Optic Chiasma:

The genu is the bend of the anterior corpus callosum and the forceps minor is a tract that projects fibres from the genu to connect the medial and lateral surfaces of the frontal lobes. The body forms the long central section and its fibres pass through the corona radiata to reach the surface of the hemispheres. The splenium tapers away at the posterior section, with the forceps major projecting fibres from the splenium to connect the two occipital lobes. The hippocampus is not connected directly to the splenium, but situated inferior to the splenium.

questions.text: The type of fibers present in the fornix are? ( INICET May 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Association and commisural fibers

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The fornix contains both association fibers (linking parts of the hippocampus to other regions within the same hemisphere) and commissural fibers (connecting the hippocampi of the two hemispheres).
  • ➤ Association fibers : These fibers connect different parts of the same hemisphere. Their function is to enable communication between different cortical areas within the same cerebral hemisphere.
  • ➤ Association fibers
  • ➤ Commissural fibers : These are axons that connect one cerebral hemisphere to the other. Their primary function is to allow the two hemispheres to communicate with each other. The corpus callosum is the most significant group of commissural fibers, but the fornix also contains commissural fibers. Specifically, fibers from the fornix contribute to the hippocampal commissure, which connects the two hippocampi of the right and left hemispheres.
  • ➤ Commissural fibers

questions.text: Which maternal layer of decidua fuses with the decidua parietalis as pregnancy advances? (Twisted PYQ)

  • • Initially forms as the endometrial tissue overlying the implanting embryo
  • • As pregnancy advances, it gradually thins and eventually fuses with decidua parietalis
  • • This fusion leads to the obliteration of the uterine cavity by week 12-14 of pregnancy

questions.text: What are the derivatives of the marked cells? (INICET MAY 2022) 1. Odontoblasts 2. Sympathetic chain 3. Melanocytes 4. Nephrogenic cord 5. Bulbus cordis 6. Conotruncal septum
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. 1, 2, 3, 6

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The cells referred to in the question are neural crest cells (NCC), identified adjacent to the neural tube (NT). These cells are significant in developmental biology and are often considered a fourth germ layer due to their extensive differentiation potential across various organs and tissues, exclusive to vertebrates. NCCs transform into various cell types based on their migration path:
  • • neural crest cells
  • • Dorsal region migration leads to the formation of sensory neurons.
  • • Ventral region migration results in the differentiation into sympathetic neurons.
  • • These cells are pivotal in developing peripheral nervous system components, craniofacial structures (including bones, cartilage, teeth, and facial muscles), and cardiovascular system components such as the heart.
  • • 1. Odontoblasts : Correct, as these are the cells responsible for dentin formation in teeth, derived from neural crest cells.
  • • 1. Odontoblasts :
  • • 2. Sympathetic chain : Correct, neural crest cells form the sympathetic ganglia, part of the autonomic nervous system.
  • • 2. Sympathetic chain :
  • • 3. Melanocytes : Correct, these pigment-producing cells in the skin and hair are derived from neural crest cells.
  • • 3. Melanocytes :
  • • 6. Conotruncal septum : Correct, this component of the heart, crucial for the division of the pulmonary artery and aorta, is derived from neural crest cells.
  • • 6. Conotruncal septum :
  • • In trunk region, NCC form:
  • • In trunk region, NCC form:
  • • Melanocytes Sensory ganglia Sympathetic and enteric neurons Schwann cells Adrenal medulla cells In the cranial region, they contribute to the: Craniofacial skeleton Neurons for cranial ganglia Satellite glial cells Melanocytes Some of the other neural crest derivatives are C cells of the thyroid gland Conotruncal septum in the heart Odontoblasts Smooth muscle cells to blood vessels to the face and forebrain.
  • • Melanocytes
  • • Sensory ganglia
  • • Sympathetic and enteric neurons
  • • Schwann cells
  • • Adrenal medulla cells
  • • In the cranial region, they contribute to the:
  • • Craniofacial skeleton
  • • Neurons for cranial ganglia
  • • Satellite glial cells
  • • Melanocytes
  • • Some of the other neural crest derivatives are
  • • C cells of the thyroid gland
  • • Conotruncal septum in the heart
  • • Odontoblasts
  • • Smooth muscle cells to blood vessels to the face and forebrain.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • 4. Nephrogenic cord : Incorrect, as it is involved in the development of the kidneys and does not derive from neural crest cells.
  • • 4. Nephrogenic cord :
  • • 5. Bulbus cordis : Incorrect, this embryonic heart structure does not originate from neural crest cells.
  • • 5. Bulbus cordis :

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Neural crest cells (NCCs), stemming from the embryonic ectoderm and unique to vertebrates, play an essential role in forming various tissues and organs like the peripheral nervous system and craniofacial structures during development. These cells migrate and differentiate into diverse cell types based on their location in the body, contributing significantly to the development of sensory and sympathetic neurons, craniofacial elements, and cardiovascular structures.

questions.text: What is the nerve supply of the structure marked in the image below? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation: Ans. B. Median nerve

questions.text: What is the nerve supply of the structure marked in the image?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Median nerve

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The median nerve supplies the 1st lumbrical which is marked.
  • • The 1st lumbrical muscle is innervated by the median nerve. It is a small, quadrilateral muscle located in the hand that arises from the tendon of the flexor digitorum profundus muscle of the index finger and inserts into the extensor expansion of the index finger. Its main function is to flex the metacarpophalangeal joint of the index finger and extend the interphalangeal joints of the index finger. The 1st lumbrical muscle is named because it is associated with the first (index) finger, and there are a total of four lumbrical muscles in the hand - one for each of the four fingers (excluding the thumb).
  • • The first and second lumbrical nerves are innervated by the median nerve. The third and fourth lumbricals are innervated by the deep terminal branch of the ulnar nerve.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Radial Nerve: The radial nerve primarily innervates the extensor muscles of the forearm and hand, including the wrist and finger extensors. It does not supply the lumbrical muscles.
  • • Option A.
  • • Radial Nerve:
  • • Option C. Ulnar Nerve: The ulnar nerve supplies several intrinsic hand muscles, including the lumbrical muscles. However, the first lumbrical is typically innervated by the median nerve, as mentioned earlier.
  • • Option C.
  • • Ulnar Nerve:
  • • Option D. Musculocutaneous Nerve: The musculocutaneous nerve primarily innervates the muscles in the anterior compartment of the arm. It does not supply the lumbrical muscles.
  • • Option D.
  • • Musculocutaneous Nerve:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ T he 1st lumbrical muscle of the hand is innervated by the median nerve is crucial for clinical assessments of hand function, especially in cases of nerve injury or compression syndromes like carpal tunnel syndrome, where the median nerve's functionality can be compromised.

questions.text: A woman with right-sided loss of sensations of both the upper and lower limb complains of shooting pain from her fingers to the right shoulder and a burning sensation when touching cold water.   • ➤ A thalamic lesion results in a breakdown in communication between the brain's afferent route and cortex because the thalamus serves as the site for the relay of sensory information between the periphery and cortex. The healing process following a thalamic infarct is painful.

questions.text: Which is the strongest layer of the esophagus? (NEET PG 2014)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Submucosa

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The submucosa is the strongest layer of the esophagus. It is composed of elastic and fibrous tissue, which provide structural integrity and strength. The esophageal wall consists of three primary layers: the mucosa, the submucosa, and the muscularis externa. The mucosa is the innermost layer, made up of squamous epithelium, lamina propria, and muscularis mucosa. The submucosa lies beneath the mucosa and contains a dense network of elastic and fibrous tissues, making it particularly robust. The muscularis externa is responsible for the peristaltic movements of the esophagus, and the outermost layer is the adventitia, which provides additional support and connects the esophagus to surrounding structures.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Mucosa: This layer is composed of squamous epithelium and is designed for protection and absorption but is not the strongest layer.
  • • Option A. Mucosa:
  • • Option C. Muscularis externa: This layer is responsible for the peristaltic movement of the esophagus but does not provide the same level of structural strength as the submucosa.
  • • Option C. Muscularis externa:
  • • Option D. Adventitia: This outer layer connects the esophagus to nearby tissues but is not the strongest layer.
  • • Option D. Adventitia:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The submucosa is the strongest layer of the esophagus, composed of elastic and fibrous tissue.

questions.text: Decussation of the superior cerebellar peduncle occurs at which level?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Midbrain

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The decussation of the superior cerebellar peduncle occurs in the midbrain, at the level of the inferior colliculus.
  • • The midbrain has four decussations:
  • • At the level of the superior colliculus: Ventral tegmental decussation of the rubrospinal tract Dorsal tegmental decussation of the tectospinal tract
  • • At the level of the superior colliculus: Ventral tegmental decussation of the rubrospinal tract Dorsal tegmental decussation of the tectospinal tract
  • • At the level of the superior colliculus:
  • • Ventral tegmental decussation of the rubrospinal tract Dorsal tegmental decussation of the tectospinal tract
  • • Ventral tegmental decussation of the rubrospinal tract
  • • Dorsal tegmental decussation of the tectospinal tract
  • • At the level of the inferior colliculus: Decussation of superior cerebellar peduncles Decussation of trochlear nerve
  • • At the level of the inferior colliculus: Decussation of superior cerebellar peduncles Decussation of trochlear nerve
  • • At the level of the inferior colliculus:
  • • Decussation of superior cerebellar peduncles Decussation of trochlear nerve
  • • Decussation of superior cerebellar peduncles
  • • Decussation of trochlear nerve
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Pons : The pons is a part of the brainstem located above the medulla and below the midbrain. It contains nuclei that deal with sleep, respiration, bladder control, hearing, taste, eye movement, facial expressions, facial sensation, and posture. While the pons does have connections with the cerebellum (mainly through the middle cerebellar peduncle), the decussation of the superior cerebellar peduncle doesn't happen here.
  • • Option A.
  • • Pons
  • • Option C . Diencephalon : The diencephalon is a region of the forebrain that includes the thalamus, hypothalamus, and epithalamus. While the superior cerebellar peduncle does send fibers to the thalamus, the decussation doesn't happen in the diencephalon.
  • • Option C
  • • Diencephalon
  • • Option D . Medulla : The medulla oblongata, commonly referred to simply as the medulla, is the lower part of the brainstem. It's continuous with the spinal cord and contains many important neural pathways and centers for autonomic functions. The medulla does contain decussations, but they are mainly associated with the pyramidal tracts (motor pathways) and not with the superior cerebellar peduncle.
  • • Option D
  • • Medulla

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The midbrain, or mesencephalon, is the uppermost part of the brainstem, lying between the pons and the diencephalon. The superior cerebellar peduncle fibers decussate (cross) in the midbrain to reach the contralateral red nucleus and thalamus. This is why lesions in the cerebellum typically affect the same side of the body: the fibers effectively "double-cross," first decussating in the midbrain and then crossing again at higher levels in the brain.

questions.text: Which of the following is normally seen in lumbar spine? ( AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Lordosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Lordosis refers to the inward (anterior) curvature of the spine. It's the normal anatomical curvature seen in the lumbar (lower back) and cervical (neck) regions. In the lumbar region, lordosis allows for an upright posture and helps to evenly distribute the body's weight and the forces exerted on the spine. While a certain degree of lumbar lordosis is normal and healthy, excessive lordosis (often called "swayback") can lead to pain and other issues.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Scoliosis: Scoliosis refers to a lateral (side-to-side) curvature of the spine. While any part of the spine can be affected, scoliosis most commonly develops in the thoracic (upper/mid back) and/or lumbar (lower back) regions. It's important to note that while scoliosis can affect the lumbar spine, it is not the normal anatomical curvature for that region. Instead, it's a pathological condition which can be idiopathic (most common, especially in adolescents), congenital, or secondary to other conditions.
  • • Option A. Scoliosis:
  • • Option B. Kyphosis: Kyphosis describes a forward (anterior) rounding or curvature of the spine, producing a "hunchback" appearance. The normal anatomical region that displays kyphosis is the thoracic spine (upper/mid back). When present in the lumbar spine, it is considered pathological and is usually secondary to conditions like osteoporosis (which causes compression fractures), degenerative diseases, or other spine disorders.
  • • Option B. Kyphosis:
  • • Option D. Recurvatum: Recurvatum typically refers to a backward bending or hyperextension of a joint. While this term can be applied to various joints in the body, it's most commonly associated with the knee joint, where the knee bends backward excessively. It doesn't directly pertain to the natural anatomical curvatures of the spine.
  • • Option D. Recurvatum:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In adults,
  • ➤ The cervical curve is a lordosis (convex forwards), The thoracic curve is a kyphosis (convex dorsally), The lumbar curve is also a lordosis, The pelvic curve is concave anteroinferiorly.
  • ➤ The cervical curve is a lordosis (convex forwards),
  • ➤ The thoracic curve is a kyphosis (convex dorsally),
  • ➤ The lumbar curve is also a lordosis,
  • ➤ The pelvic curve is concave anteroinferiorly.

questions.text: A patient presented with the extension of MCP joint and flexion of IP joints. Which muscle is affected?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Interossei and lumbricals

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Interossei and lumbricals are the intrinsic muscles of the hand.
  • ➤ Interossei and lumbricals
  • ➤ The lumbricals arise from the tendons of the flexor digitorum profundus. They act to flex the MCP joints and extend both the proximal and distal IP joints. The interossei (both dorsal and palmar) act to abduct (DAB - Dorsal Abduct) and adduct (PAD - Palmar Adduct) the fingers at the MCP joints and assist the lumbricals in flexing the MCP joints and extending the IP joints. If these muscles are affected, as indicated in the clinical picture, there would be an extension of the MCP joints and flexion of the IP joints (due to unopposed action of extrinsic flexors and extensors).
  • ➤ The lumbricals arise from the tendons of the flexor digitorum profundus. They act to flex the MCP joints and extend both the proximal and distal IP joints.
  • ➤ The interossei (both dorsal and palmar) act to abduct (DAB - Dorsal Abduct) and adduct (PAD - Palmar Adduct) the fingers at the MCP joints and assist the lumbricals in flexing the MCP joints and extending the IP joints.
  • ➤ If these muscles are affected, as indicated in the clinical picture, there would be an extension of the MCP joints and flexion of the IP joints (due to unopposed action of extrinsic flexors and extensors).

questions.text: From which germ layer are astrocytes derived? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Astrocytes are derived from neuroectoderm. Neuroectoderm is a specialized portion of ectoderm that forms the neural tube and neural crest. The neural tube gives rise to the central nervous system, including neurons and neuroglial cells. Astrocytes are a type of neuroglial cell that form within the central nervous system. They develop from glioblasts (also called spongioblasts), which in turn derive from the germinal neuroepithelial cells of the neural tube wall after they cease to produce neuroblasts.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option a) Mesoderm - This is incorrect because mesoderm gives rise to structures like bone, cartilage, muscle, blood, connective tissue, and the urogenital system. While mesoderm contributes to the vascular elements in the nervous system and forms microglia (which are mesodermal in origin), it does not form astrocytes.
  • • Option a) Mesoderm
  • • Option c) Endoderm - This is incorrect because endoderm gives rise to the epithelial lining of the respiratory tract, gastrointestinal tract, bladder, and associated glands. Endoderm has no role in forming any components of the central nervous system, including astrocytes.
  • • Option c) Endoderm
  • • Option d) None - This is incorrect because astrocytes definitely have a germ layer of origin, which is neuroectoderm.
  • • Option d) None
  • • Education Objective:
  • • Education Objective:
  • • Astrocytes are neuroglial cells that develop from glioblasts derived from the neuroepithelial cells of the neural tube, making them neuroectodermal in origin. This is consistent with most of the cellular elements of the central nervous system which derive from neuroectoderm

questions.text: Identify the ocular component that originates from neural crest cells. (NEET PG 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The choroid is derived from neural crest cells during embryonic development. Neural crest cells are a special population of cells that originate from the neural tube's edges. During eye development, these cells migrate to form various ocular structures including the choroid, which is the vascular layer between the retina and sclera. The choroid is part of the uveal tract and provides nutrients to the outer retinal layers through its rich vascular network.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Descemet's membrane : This is not derived from neural crest cells but from neural ectoderm. It's the basement membrane of the corneal endothelium and is secreted by the endothelial cells. Option B. Extraocular muscles : These develop from the mesoderm (specifically from prechordal mesoderm and somitomeres), not from neural crest cells. They include the six muscles that control eye movement. Option C. Vitreous body : This clear gel filling the posterior segment of the eye develops primarily from mesenchymal cells of mesodermal origin, not neural crest cells.
  • • Option A. Descemet's membrane : This is not derived from neural crest cells but from neural ectoderm. It's the basement membrane of the corneal endothelium and is secreted by the endothelial cells.
  • • Option A. Descemet's membrane
  • • Option B. Extraocular muscles : These develop from the mesoderm (specifically from prechordal mesoderm and somitomeres), not from neural crest cells. They include the six muscles that control eye movement.
  • • Option B. Extraocular muscles
  • • Option C. Vitreous body : This clear gel filling the posterior segment of the eye develops primarily from mesenchymal cells of mesodermal origin, not neural crest cells.
  • • Option C. Vitreous body
  • • Education Objective:
  • • Education Objective:
  • • Neural crest cells contribute significantly to ocular development, giving rise to the choroid, corneal endothelium, stroma, melanocytes, ciliary body, and iris stroma, but not to structures like Descemet's membrane, extraocular muscles, or the vitreous body.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is NOT involved in forming the rotator cuff? (NEET PG 2014)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Teres major

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The rotator cuff is composed of four muscles: subscapularis, supraspinatus, infraspinatus, and teres minor. These muscles play a critical role in stabilizing the shoulder joint by keeping the head of the humerus firmly within the shallow socket of the scapula. The teres major, on the other hand, does not contribute to the rotator cuff. It is located inferior to the teres minor and functions mainly in the internal rotation and adduction of the humerus.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Infraspinatus: This muscle is part of the rotator cuff and is responsible for external rotation of the shoulder.
  • • Option B. Infraspinatus:
  • • Option C. Subscapularis: This muscle is also part of the rotator cuff and allows for internal rotation of the shoulder.
  • • Option C. Subscapularis:
  • • Option D. Supraspinatus: This muscle is a member of the rotator cuff and assists in abduction of the shoulder.
  • • Option D. Supraspinatus:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Teres major is not a part of the rotator cuff, which is formed by the subscapularis, supraspinatus, infraspinatus, and teres minor muscles.

questions.text: A patient came with complaints of inability to move his 4th and 5th digit, cannot hold a pen and he was not able to hold a paper between fingers. Which of the following sites given below is the probable cause of injury to the nerve in question? ( AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. 7

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tests for ulnar nerve lesions are as follows:
  • ➤ Tests for ulnar nerve lesions are as follows:
  • ➤ 1. Card Test : This isn't a widely recognized test in the context of ulnar nerve pathology. However, in some practices, the card test might refer to asking the patient to hold a card (like a credit card) between their thumb and the side of their index finger. Difficulty or inability to do this due to a weak adductor pollicis muscle (innervated by the ulnar nerve) may suggest ulnar nerve dysfunction.
  • ➤ 1. Card Test
  • ➤ 2. Claw Hand Deformity : This is seen in ulnar nerve injuries. In a typical ulnar claw hand, the 4th and 5th digits (ring and little fingers) are hyperextended at the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints and flexed at the interphalangeal (IP) joints. This occurs due to the loss of function of the lumbricals and interossei of the hand, which are innervated by the ulnar nerve.
  • ➤ 2. Claw Hand Deformity
  • ➤ 3. Froment's Sign : This is a classic sign of ulnar nerve palsy. The patient is asked to hold a piece of paper between their thumb and the side of their index finger (pinch grip). If the ulnar nerve is compromised, the patient will compensate by flexing the thumb's IP joint to maintain grip strength, which is a positive Froment's sign. This indicates weakness or paralysis of the adductor pollicis muscle.
  • ➤ 3. Froment's Sign
  • ➤ 4. Wartenberg Sign : In ulnar nerve injury, there's unopposed action of the extensor digiti minimi, which leads to abduction of the little finger. The patient will be unable to bring their little finger back to the side of the hand, leading to the "Wartenberg sign."
  • ➤ 4. Wartenberg Sign
  • ➤ 5. Palmaris Brevis Sign : This is a sign of ulnar nerve functionality. The palmaris brevis muscle is innervated by the ulnar nerve. Upon tapping or massaging the hypothenar eminence (palm side of the hand, base of the little finger), contraction of the palmaris brevis muscle can be observed as a twitching or dimpling. If present, it indicates that at least part of the ulnar nerve's function remains intact.
  • ➤ 5. Palmaris Brevis Sign

questions.text: During a surgical procedure in the ear, the surgeon injured a nerve which led to lagophthalmos after the surgery. Which nerve was likely to be damaged? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The facial nerve (Cranial Nerve 7) controls the muscles of facial expression, including the orbicularis oculi muscle, and injury to this nerve can result in lagophthalmos.

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement regarding the marked structure: (INICET MAY 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: It is the meeting point of frontal, parietal, temporal and sphenoid bones.

options.label: B
options.text: Blow to the lateral side of the skull injures the marked structure.

options.label: C
options.text: Accessory middle meningeal artery lies under this structure.

options.label: D
options.text: It corresponds to site of anterolateral fontanelle of fetal skull.

questions.correct_answer: C. Accessory middle meningeal artery lies under this structure.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Accessory middle meningeal artery lies under this structure.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The structure marked in the image is the pterion. The main branch of Middle meningeal artery lies under this structure NOT accessory middle meningeal artery. The accessory middle meningeal artery usually arises from the maxillary artery and enters the middle cranial fossa through the foramen ovale or a separate foramen. Its location and presence can vary.
  • • Other Options :
  • • Other Options
  • • Option A. It is the meeting point of frontal, parietal, temporal, and sphenoid bones. Correct : The pterion is indeed the meeting point of these four bones.
  • • Option A.
  • • It is the meeting point of frontal, parietal, temporal, and sphenoid bones.
  • • Correct
  • • Option B. Blow to the lateral side of the skull injures the marked structure. Correct : A blow to the pterion can be very dangerous because the middle meningeal artery runs just deep to this area, on the inner side of the skull. If this artery is ruptured due to a fracture at the pterion, it can lead to an epidural hematoma, which is a type of traumatic brain injury.
  • • Option B.
  • • Blow to the lateral side of the skull injures the marked structure. Correct
  • • Option D. It corresponds to the site of the anterolateral fontanelle of the fetal skull. Correct : The pterion corresponds to the region of the anterolateral (or sphenoid) fontanelle in the fetal skull. This fontanelle usually closes a few months after birth.
  • • Option D.
  • • It corresponds to the site of the anterolateral fontanelle of the fetal skull. Correct

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pterion is the junction point of four bones in the skull: the frontal, parietal, temporal, and sphenoid bones. The term "pterion" comes from the Greek word "pteron," meaning "wing," because the pterion is located at the point where the sphenoid bone and the temporal bone form a wing-like shape. The pterion is located just above the zygomatic arch and anterior to the ear. The middle meningeal artery, a branch of the maxillary artery, runs underneath the pterion and is at risk of injury in cases of head trauma.

questions.text: A patient presents with swelling below the left earlobe and is experiencing pain. What is the most likely cause of this pain? (NEET PG 2023)

options.label: B
options.text: Investing layer of deep cervical fascia

questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Greater auricular nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Greater auricular nerve originates from the cervical plexus, specifically from the C2 and C3 spinal nerves. It ascends to the parotid gland and provides sensory innervation to the skin over the parotid gland, the earlobe, and the area behind the ear, so the greater auricular nerve is most directly responsible for transmitting pain sensations from these regions.
  • ➤ Greater auricular nerve

questions.text: The structure marked with the black arrow in the given picture arises from the ……… ( AIIMS May 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Hippocampus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This is a coronal section of the brain and the marked structure is the fornix. It arises from the hippocampus and ends in the mammillary body of the hypothalamus.
  • • Hippocampus is located in the medial temporal lobe of the brain.
  • • Hippocampus
  • • The hippocampus is critical for the formation and retrieval of memories, particularly episodic memories. It's also involved in spatial navigation. Damage or atrophy of the hippocampus can result in difficulties forming new memories. Conditions like Alzheimer's disease often exhibit significant hippocampal atrophy.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Mamillary body : Part of the diencephalon, present at the base of the brain, posterior to the pituitary gland.
  • • Option A. Mamillary body
  • • The mammillary bodies are primarily associated with memory processing. They receive projections from the hippocampus via the fornix and send projections to the anterior nucleus of the thalamus. They're particularly involved in the recall of past memories and are thought to play a role in spatial memory. Damage to the mammillary bodies, often due to thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency as seen in Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, can lead to memory deficits.
  • • The mammillary bodies are primarily associated with memory processing. They receive projections from the hippocampus via the fornix and send projections to the anterior nucleus of the thalamus. They're particularly involved in the recall of past memories and are thought to play a role in spatial memory. Damage to the mammillary bodies, often due to thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency as seen in Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, can lead to memory deficits.
  • • Option C. Thalamus: Positioned centrally in the brain, the thalamus is a large mass of gray matter deep within the brain. It is part of the diencephalon.
  • • Option C.
  • • Thalamus:
  • • Often referred to as the "relay station" of the brain, the thalamus receives sensory and motor signals and relays them to the cerebral cortex. It's involved in consciousness, sleep, and alertness. Thalamic strokes or lesions can lead to sensory deficits, altered consciousness, and movement disorders.
  • • Often referred to as the "relay station" of the brain, the thalamus receives sensory and motor signals and relays them to the cerebral cortex. It's involved in consciousness, sleep, and alertness. Thalamic strokes or lesions can lead to sensory deficits, altered consciousness, and movement disorders.
  • • Option D. Amygdala : Located in the anterior portion of the temporal lobe, deep within the brain.
  • • Option D.
  • • Amygdala
  • • The amygdala plays a pivotal role in processing emotions, particularly fear and pleasure. It helps determine which memories are stored and where they are stored based on emotional significance. Dysfunction of the amygdala can lead to various emotional and behavioral abnormalities. It's also implicated in conditions such as anxiety disorders and post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD).

Dysfunction of the amygdala can lead to various emotional and behavioral abnormalities. It's also implicated in conditions such as anxiety disorders and post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD).

questions.text: A patient presented with a fall on an outstretched hand. On X-ray, a fracture of the base of the 1st metacarpal bone was seen. This type of fracture is also known as: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bennett's fracture is an intra-articular fracture at the base of the first metacarpal bone, commonly caused by a fall on an outstretched hand. It is important to recognize this fracture due to its involvement with the CMC joint and potential for dislocation.
